segments.text: It kept me going, you know.
Regardless if I like to do what I'm doing, I just did it.
Because that was my job.
Yeah, it was my job.
Well, let's talk about this occupation duty as far as it's concerned.
Here you are, first lieutenant in charge of a hundred thousand white Russians in Austria in three different camps.
How were part of your functions and duties not only to take care of those people as far as health, clothing, et cetera, but also ordering food?
And tell me about your staff.
Yeah, well, we had the artillery battalion staff.
See, I was the battalion headquarters commander.
And of course, at my disposal, I had the whole staff to work with.
headquarter staff.
So I had enough help.
I had plenty of help.
Ordering the food, no problem.
The staff did it.
And I supervised the staff.
Okay, now you said that these people were really rather pathetic.
Their human condition was pathetic.
What did they think of the Americans?
Oh, they liked the Americans.
They did.
These were people like me and you.
You know, they
They respected the Americans.
They had great respect.
I'd walk into these DP camps, and they were very, not because of the military, but because of them being American.
And I didn't really have time to communicate with a lot of them, talk to them, or visit with them, because we were too damn busy.
Like you say, getting medicine, food, clothing, getting them broken down into families, and getting them all together.
and make sure the boxcars were available and make sure transportation was on time and stuff like this.

And so I didn't really have time to, as much as I wanted to, was to get out and visit with them and see where they're from and what kind of work they did or, you know, just try to find something out about them.
Just didn't have the time.
Or probably very few of them spoke English anyway.
No, they didn't speak English at all.
Only the girls spoke English.
Oh, really?
Yeah, the girls we'd run across, you know, in camp.
I'm talking about 19, 20, 21-year-old girls.
And there were plenty of them.
There weren't many men.
Most of them were women.
Most of these were women?
Women, yeah.
Of course the men were... Dead.
Dead, yeah.
And so...
And kids, of course.
They had kids while they were there.
They intermarried and developed families.
They'd been there five, six years.
Sure.
And seven years.
And so we had to get them all processed and get them out of there.
Now, how did you go about processing them?
You got their name and where they were supposedly from and their citizenship and just basic paperwork on them?
Well, we sent them to Linz, Austria.
And Linz would
We'd put them in, actually, we'd put them on trucks and send them in to Lynn's, and Lynn's division headquarters there would put them in the boxcars and get them on the trains and send them back.
So we had a certain procedure we followed.
And were the camps like dormitories with barbed wire around?
Oh yeah, barbed wire.
Actually, they were the regular labor camps.
But the Germans, we just went in there and cleaned them up.
When I got there, it was all set up.
They had cleaned up the camps and modernized them and had medical facilities available and everything.
Started feeding these people.
Oh, yeah.
See, when I got there, they'd already been set up and ready to go.
So they just took over the same slave labor camps that the people were already in.
And what kind of work were they doing?
Agricultural?
Agriculture work, road work, just whatever.
During the day and night they put them back in the camps.
Up in the mountains.
Cumberland Mountains they called it.
Well actually part of the Alps.
They called them the Cumberland area.
Now, did any of them try to, realizing what their fate would be in the Soviet Union, did any of them try to escape?
Oh, yeah, that was our problem.
That's what we used all the men for, was to guard the camps.
Yeah, they tried.
I don't blame them.
I really don't blame them.
Were they ever successful?
Some of them got away, and of course we'd have to go try to find them.
Some of them we brought back, and some of them we just couldn't find.
Oh, yeah.
We couldn't understand why we were sending them back.
Just couldn't understand it.
Yeah, and this is a big dilemma.
It is.
And of course, like I said, my A&M training, you know, it's a job, and we had to do it.
Had to go through it.
But we had a treaty with the Soviets.
Yeah, we had a treaty.
We knew that.
But we couldn't understand the treaty.
Why did Roosevelt get us into this situation?
Or Eisenhower?
The reason behind this is so we could have our prisoner wars or anybody that the Russians captured back.
That was the idea.
So it was supposed to be a trade-off.
Of course there were a lot more Russians on our side than there were Americans on their side.
But there were some Americans and they wanted those back.
But they wanted the white Russians back.
And the Ukrainians.
Ukrainians and the Slovaks and the Polaks and anything they could.
You know, oh yeah.
Romanians, we found a battalion of Romanian SS troopers in a camp.
Yeah, they were just living.
They didn't care.
The war was over.
They were just, they stacked their arms and they made camp.
And so they were a whole battalion of them.
So I went back and told the colonel, I said, there's a whole battalion of SS troopers up there.
Where, where, where?
I said, up there in the mountains.
So we went up there and
I turned over the colonel.
I don't know what the hell he did with them.
They finally sent them to PW camp because they were SS troopers.
But they weren't bothering anybody.
They were just sitting there living.
They knew the war was over.
So they were smart.
In fact, you couldn't find any arms.
They had taken them and stacked them and put them in a
in a storeroom and locked them up so nobody had arms.
So when the colonel went up there with the MPs, I don't know, they just joined them, you know, and next thing I knew they'd moved them all out to Williams, Austria, to P.W.
Cage.
It was funny.
Now did you ever come in contact with the Russian troops?
Only in Czechoslovakia.
Now you were with the Eighth Armored, and this is the one that went into Czechoslovakia but didn't liberate Prague, is that right?
That's right.
And you stood on the outskirts, or can you describe that situation?
We went to Pilsen and stopped.
We stopped at Pilsen.
See, first we went to the Elbe River, and then they stopped us at Elbe and sent us into the Harts Mountain.
And we fought there the Hitler-Jugend.
And we tried to find that underground railroad they were supposed to have, but we never did find it.
And then the war was over.
So then they sent us to Czechoslovakia.
In the meantime, Patton had gone into Czechoslovakia and liberated them and gone up towards Prague.
And Eisenhower stopped him, told him not to go into Prague.
That was Russia.
He said, well, hell, I'm going to take Prague.
He said, no.
So he pulled him back, and they had a line drawn between Pilsen and Prague, and that was it.
And where we'd see the Russians was, they'd come into Pilsen to buy, and they were tourists.
Because we couldn't go into Prague.
They wouldn't let us go over there, but the Russians are.
And a lot of them came in with knapsacks, five years of pay.
Never got paid till the war was over, and they had five years of money in their knapsack.
So they were buying everything.
Mickey Mouse watches, $100, $200 a piece.
And you could buy them for $2.50 in the country.
But they would buy cigarettes, $100 a carton.
Really?
Oh, they were giving money away.
And the G.I.s would just sell them a Jeep.
And then report it stolen, and when they get to the checkpoint, the American MPs would confiscate the jeep and send the Russians on back.
Oh, yeah.
They had money, five years of pay.
My goodness.
And the Czechoslovakians did not want them in there.
No.
No.
Hated them.
Didn't want them.
And so then we were ordered out of there.
It was July, early July, somewhere.
First of all.
Early July, yeah.
Yeah, we were ordered out of there.
And the Czechs cried.
Didn't want us to leave.
We were good to them.
We brought food in.
We brought medicine in.
And we shared it.
We stayed in the homes.
Oh, did you?
Oh, yeah.
We lived in the homes.
It's like you move in here with me.
Really?
Yeah.
That's where we lived.
We lived in the homes.
What did they think of that?
They loved it.
We loved it.
Yeah, we were living in homes instead of in tents on the ground.
They cooked meals for us.
Oh, they cooked meals for you?
Oh, yeah, they cooked meals for us.
But we had our own mess tent.
And would you buy the meals?
Oh, we'd give them money.
We'd bring them food.
They couldn't get beer.
Pilsen, Czechoslovakia had the biggest brewer in Europe, and they couldn't get the beer.
Why was that?
They wouldn't give the civilians any alcohol.
But we could get the beer.
So we'd get the beer we wanted, and then...
give it to our Czechoslovakia friends.
In fact, we'd throw parties for them.
Let them throw the party, and we'd furnish the food.
And we'd do all the Slavic dances.
Oh, they loved us.
They loved us.
When I left, they brought flowers out to me.
People I lived with named Trojan cried, gave me a vase full of flowers.
I still got the vase.
They cried.
They loved it.
They loved us.
And I used to correspond with them when I got back to the States.
And finally, a letter got out that says, please don't write us.
No kidding?
That's right.
The Russians wrote it.
That was after 48?
Right.
Oh, yeah.
The Russians were really giving them hell.
So if they were communicating with Americans, they were Russians.
I don't know what they did to them.
People I lived with at Trojan's had a baker shop downstairs, and we lived upstairs.
It was fun, I tell you.
I had fresh pastry and rolls and bread.
That must have been welcoming after being on the road.
Oh, it really was.
It really was.
You say they hated the Russians.
They really did.
What were your opinions?
Did you have any, besides just seeing the Russians,
What were your impressions?
Do you remember other Russians?
Well, I never did really run across any of them except I'd see them in Pilsen.
I stayed clear of them.
You know, I knew what they were and so I stayed, I didn't try to get involved with any, talk with them, drink with them.
I just... Did many men do that?
Well, yeah, the men did.
They'd just buy them drinks and stuff.
I don't think- So their relations were pretty good?
Pretty good, yeah.
They were good in Pillson.
We didn't have any trouble with them at all.
I'd go to the clubs, and the Russians would be there with the men, drinking, socializing.
So it was good.
No problem at all.
But I can't recall any vis-a-vis with the Russians.
What's that?
You know, I was wondering that they would put you in charge of an occupation camp or a displaced person camp with your Greek background.
Do you think that had anything to do with it?
I mean, the fact that you were a European background?
European background?
Yeah.
I don't believe that.
Or was it just because of you?
Just because of my job being the headquartered commandant.
I was headquartered commandant of the battalion, and that was my job.
Okay.
Do you want to move on now to, would you have to go now?
I'm going to have to go.
Yeah, I need to go to the office.
Okay, fine.
Okay, then we can talk tomorrow morning.
We can start on when you are released from active duty, or we can finish up anything else you want to talk about on active duty.
Tomorrow?
Tomorrow morning.
Yeah.
Okay.
Yeah, let's do that tomorrow.
You want to come back tonight?
All right.
This is a second interview with General Mike P. Kokonos, and today is June 2, 1981.
Last time we were talking, and I think pretty much finished up your active wartime career.
I was wondering if you had thought of anything else that you might want to mention before we move on to your reserve career.
I can't recall of anything that I think of something later.
Okay, fine.
Then let's go to your reserve.
Period.
And what rank were you when you left?
When did you get out?
When were you discharged?
And what rank?
From the reserve?
No, from the active duty.
I was discharged as a captain in 1946.
Okay.
July of 1946, I was discharged as a captain at Fort Sam Houston.
Okay, so they sent you back there.
Right.
All right.
Had you given any thought as a captain?
Had you given any thought at all
to stay in the military and make it a career?
None at all.
I had not thought about it.
I wanted to get home and try to pick up where I left off from school and get back into medical school.
And that was my main objective was to try to get back into medical school.
Did you think at that time that you would ever have the possibility of staying in the reserves and becoming general?
No, did not.
Never entertained the idea of it.
And I liked the Army.
I thought it was good.
But I thought that at the time that I served well and felt good about it, and so I was just going to come home and become a good civilian and go to medical school.
OK.
Now, in 1947, you organized the 143rd Reserve National Guard.
Were you authorized to do that?
Tell me about that.
How did you create that, and who else was involved?
Could you tell me that story?
Yes, I was sitting at home one afternoon on Hazel Street, and Harold Simmons, who's a first sergeant in the regular army, and he is since now deceased,
came to me and he said, Mike, we're trying to organize a National Guard company here in Beaumont.
Are you interested in being part of it?
I told him I really wasn't.
I just didn't feel that, you know, I was ready.
I'd just come out of the Army and I just didn't feel like participating in the National Guard.
I really didn't know too much about the Guard.
I'd heard the reserves were
All I knew was reserves, but the guard, as I found out, was state troops and commanded by the governor.
Anyway, he persuaded me to organize an infantry company, H Company, of the 143rd, which was a heavy weapons company, machine guns, mortars, and rockets.
And so we organized at the downtown YMCA.
It was in the gym, and it was 12 of us.

Twelve of us got it started, and some of the men were Harold Simmons, of course, Clark Phippen, P-H-I-P-P-E-N, and Lee Quisenberry, who incidentally, Lee came to me as a carpal at that time and stayed with me during my whole career and was my sergeant major wherever I went.
I took him with me, and he has died about a year ago.
So we lost Lee with a heart attack.
But Harold Summons, and we had the former mayor of Beaumont, Lowry, that was in there.
But anyway, we got organized.
And we had to do it all ourselves.
I mean.
What about the politics of this?
Well, at the time, I didn't know anything about the politics.
Didn't realize that the National Guard had politics in it.
Probably wouldn't have gotten involved if I'd known it.
I really didn't know too much about the Guard.
We were never told.
I mean, well, I never knew anything about the Guard or the Reserve because I was always in.
Activity.
Yeah, activity or in school and never concerned myself with it.
But I remember my older brother, Janelle, was in the CMTC, but they called it the Guard then.
He went to a guard camp one year when I remember as a kid.
CMTC.
A civilian military training corps.
I take it back.
He didn't get in the CMTC.
He got into the National Guard.
It was C Company, the Guard, here in Beaumont.
And so he went to camp.
And he went to camp in somebody else's place and used their name.
So that's the only thing I remember about the Guard.
We organized the H Company.
And I went to the city and asked them to help us secure a place to train.
So they said they would let us use the fairgrounds.
And we went to the fairgrounds, and we took over a building.
And then the guard bureau, the state guard bureau, gave us some money to put in some wooden offices and stuff.
So that's where we got started.
So you got money from the state bureau in Austin?
Austin.
They helped us to build the armor.
to put our weapons, our guns in.
Where'd you get the guns?
They, Texas, the National Guard sent them to us.
They were carbines and machine guns and also Recarless rifles.
And, but we got started.
First thing you know, we had a full complement.
Really?
Yes.
How many men then?
We had about 110 men.
And that's what they, that was the,
Guard limit.
Infantry Company is much larger on active duty, but they allowed us up to 110, and we had 110.
And in fact, one of my men, who lives in College Station right now, retired from the Army after I helped him get into West Point through the Guard, Charlie Zip.
He was standing in ranks one day, and a message came down from Guard Bureau, says, anybody wants to go to
West Point in your unit, just let us know.
So I asked Charlie Zipper, would he be interested in going to the military academy?
He said, never heard of it.
Didn't know anything about it.
Well, after discussing it with his mother, he come back and says, yes, I'd like to give it a try.
And through competitive tests, he was selected, made a career in the Army.
And now he's retired.
I think he retired as a colonel.
He lives in Bryan.
And of course,
He, every time he sees me, he just always thanks me for helping him.
And Terry, I get this all the time now.
I see young kids.
Oh, it really is.
I see young men today, and they come up to me, and they'll say, General, don't you remember when I was in your unit in the Guard?
And now here he is, a doctor.
Giglio lives around the corner.
He's just one, for example.
He's a doctor.
He was in my unit.
He says, you helped me out.
He says, you really did, you know.
But anyway, we went on.
The guard company was organized.
Now, you didn't want to do it.
Here we are in 1947.
The nation's army is demobilizing.
We have 12 million men in the armed forces in 1945 and 1947.
We have a million and a half.
So everybody's leaving the service.
Yet you people decide to set up a military base
station.
Now, why is that?
I guess we're deep, deep rooted in protecting our country.
We felt that we, after we, Sergeant Simmons and I, we talked about it and that's what convinced me that we needed to have some kind of militia or reserve.
We knew everybody was demobilizing and what would the army be?
Probably nothing, so
We needed some kind of reserve in case something did happen immediately, and that motivated me to take over this company.

Did you ever think that the Russians, Soviets, who at one time were a great ally during 1945, then by 1947 in the Truman Doctrine were our great nemesis, did you ever think that that might have had some influence?
Yes, that certainly did, because I knew way back during the war the Russians were not high.
true allies.
They were, in fact, for a little bit of an order from Eisenhower, we would have turned and fought the Russians.
The Germans would have helped us.
They said so.
They surrendered to us.
And so that was in the back of my mind when we organized the National Guard Company.
The Russians may want to try to do something now that we're demobilizing, because they weren't demobilizing.
No, no, they weren't demobilizing at all.
We knew that.
In fact, they were in Czechoslovakia, in Poland.
They were going to get into Poland then.
And so we knew they weren't demobilizing.
They were in Vienna.
And so that, when Simmons talked to me about it, that excited me to just do something.
Another aspect about the National Guard and about the reserves in general is
is many times officers had to buy their own uniforms.
They had to buy their own equipment.
They didn't get paid.
Tell me about how that worked as far as, did you get paid?
Tell me about how that worked.
I'm trying to remember if I really got paid or not.
It really didn't make any difference.
Yes, we did receive, we received, we drilled 48 drills, but we only got paid for half, if I remember correctly.
for 24 drills.
And then, of course, any staff meetings or anything like that, and travel, we did it ourselves.
And went to summer camp, of course, we got paid.
Is that the way it is today?
Or do you get paid for every drill?
You get paid for every drill.
And it's an extra drill.
If you have extra drills, you get paid for it.
Oh, sure.
And they pick up your travel, too, don't they?
Pick up your travel.
They'd pick up, as a general officer, when I used to travel around the country visiting the units, they paid for that.
They paid per diem, which was good.
Now, it's an odd thing.
No, they didn't pay us the same per diem.
They paid the active Army people.
It was a little less.
But I think now it's stabilized and standard.
They pay everybody the same.
But in the Guard days, we had to make ship.
You know, if we wanted to
We needed stationery.
We'd get our own stationery and typewriter.
We'd get our own typewriter.
Of course, the Guard didn't have anything.
They furnished the guns and ammunition for rifle practice.
And what kind of training did you have?
We had regular infantry training out at the fire grounds.
Basically marching and drilling?
The basic training, yeah, the squad drills.
It was basic training because we really had recruits in our...
There were a few veterans, Bill Selvin, Lieutenant Selvin, Lieutenant Engman.
They were all veterans, and they'd come out, they'd join.
It's a funny thing, Terry.
At the time, we were organized, and when I'd go around asking officers to join, they were willing to join.
I mean, I didn't have much resistance as we do today, you know,
You talk to an officer who comes with a lack of duty and tell him to get in reserve, and it doesn't excite him at all until it's too late, like 20 years later.
They tell me, well, why didn't you make me get in the reserve?
I see them today, my age, you know.
Well, why didn't you make me stay in the reserve?
Why didn't you make me make my 20?
But at that time, we didn't have any problem getting officers to.
And we went to Fort Hood by train.
We left here at midnight and got in Fort Hood about 24 hours later.
It took us that long to go from Beaumont to Fort Hood by train.
And we used one of the baggage cars for our mess haul.
And so we cooked the meals on the train.
But we got to summer camp.
It was good.
We had realistic training.
Who trained you?
We trained ourselves.
There wasn't any active army people advising or anything.
We just laid out our training schedules and went to the field.
But no active army people in training.
Was there a lot of tension between the active and the reservists?
At that time?
No, because they weren't really involved with us as much as they are today.
And I was in the 36th division.
General Ainsworth was commanding general, Miller Ainsworth.
My regimental commander was General Ives.
And we trained well, very well.
Because you know, we come out of active army, combat.
We trained like combat.
And we played like combat.
You know, at night, officers club time.
Captain Wheeler was a headquarter commandant, and he and I were good friends at A&M.
He was in combat and I was in combat.
By the way, what's his name, Artie Murphy?
Yeah, Artie Murphy, the most decorated, yeah.
Yeah, he was on our staff.
Really?
At 36th Division.
And Artie and I became very good friends because we played ping pong at night.
No kidding?
That's right.
And M.B.
Etheridge from Huntsville
had more decorations than Marty Murphy, except he didn't get the Congressional Medal of Honor.
Marty Murphy and M.B.
Ethers were both in the third division.
And M.B.
is now chairman of the bank in Huntsville.
Oh, great guy, colorful, little shark fellow.
And he had, I had H company, he had C company.
Marty Murphy was on the staff, and at night,
So Audie Murphy stayed in the reserves?
Stayed in the reserves.
I know then he went to movies.
Then he went to the movies.
He stayed in there two years.
Went to Fort Hood one year and went to Fort Polk the next year and then he went to the movies.
What kind of person was Audie Murphy?
Very quiet, nice, just pleasant as he can be.
And we played ping pong.
We'd go to the officer's club and they had this ping pong table so we'd play ping pong and talk and visit.
just ordinary, quiet, he was more of an introvert than he was an extrovert.
And of course all the recruits when they, Artie, that's what his job was to come out and recruit training.
Recruits would come out there and they'd see Artie Murphy, boy they just, everybody was thrilled that he would be there.
And he did a good job for the Texas National Guard.
It's sad, you know, he died.
When did he die?
I know he made a couple of movies, and then what happened?
Do you remember?
I don't.
Did he become an alcoholic?
Yeah, he and his wife had problems, and I think he crashed an airplane, no, an automobile crashed.
It's been so long, I just can't remember.
But he sure was a fine fellow.
Well, let's move to your reserve duties and start tracing your reserve career.
So from 1947 to 1956, you were with the 143rd.
Right.
I got promoted to major.
Oh, so you moved up.
I moved up as the operation officer, S3.
And I went to Houston for drills in.
The old light guard division, that's what they called them, on the old Spanish Trail.
And that's right, I was there.
Then politics got involved.
OK, tell me about that.
Oh, yeah, they began to play politics.
Who was they?
The action general and division headquarters.
They began to move men around and put them in command position who weren't really qualified.
And then they began to, when there was election coming on,
going to beat the drums for their candidate.
So it kind of disenchanted me with the guard, and I said, no, I didn't want any part of that.
So then that's when I transferred over to the Army Reserve.
Now, before we do that, let's talk about Korea.
Why did you feel that you should have been called up, or did you feel any, what did you think about Korea?
Well, we were alerted, but we were never called up.
I feel this way and feel strongly about it.
if you're in a reserve unit, you're a trained person, and you should be called.
Korea, Vietnam, didn't make any difference.
We ought to have been called up to fight the war, because we were better trained than the draftee that they called us.
That's just the point.
That's the reason for the reserves, I thought.
Yeah, I agree.
And what bothers me, and it bothered me, even in the Vietnam, it bothered me more in the Vietnam area, because
Here they would take a young man, no training at all, and send him for six months, and on the seventh month he was in combat.
It's not fair.
It's not right.
Here we in World War II called up, go to basic training, go to advanced training, go to an active Army unit, and train for a year as a unit before they send you overseas.
And here in Korea and in Vietnam they'd take a kid,
17, 18, 19 years old, six months, sent him to Fort Polk for six months training, and then seventh month, eighth month, he's in combat.
Just not right.
I don't believe it.
I would never, and that six months training is good training.
No question about it, but not for combat.
I think that's the fallacy of the Vietnam conflict, that these poor kids over there didn't know what to do, and they had leaders who didn't know what to do.
Of course, I read all of this, you know.
And then talk to these people who come back.
At the Command General Staff College, when I'd go up there and visit with them, and I could detect that some of the officers just didn't have the leadership.
And so I'm a strong believer that...
But you thought you should have gone in Korea.
I really do.
I think the 36th Division should have been called up and gone into Korea.
Of course, we had two years, almost three years of
of training.
Now tell me how and why you switched to the Army Reserve and got out of the National Guard.
And was this a big problem?
Bureaucratically speaking was it a real pain to do that or was it an easy maneuver or how does this work?
Well it wasn't a big pain to move except my superiors didn't want me to move.
They wanted me to stay in the Guard, and I didn't want to stay in the Guard.
Because of the politics?
Because of the politics of getting involved.
Now, could you give me a specific example of political pressure that you felt?
I'm trying to remember who was the governor.
They were trying to tell us that they wanted a certain man to, they wanted us to vote for him.
And that kind of, it was all right to say we,
You know, if they support a man, that's right, but not come around in a military armory meeting and suggest that we vote for this man.
That wasn't as bad as it was when they started moving men, moving officers above other officers who weren't really qualified to be put in those positions.
That's what really made me want to move out of the Guard.
So you thought on a state level it was just not as professional and more politically, I wouldn't want to say corrupt, but more politically influenced than on a federal level with the Army Reserve.
That's correct.
Would you agree with that?
I'd agree with that.
There's politics in the Army Reserve, but not as prevalent as it is in the Guard.
Okay.
Yeah.
More so in the officer corps.
And the Guard is just riddled with politics.
And I just couldn't.
You found that distasteful.
It was very distasteful.
And it got worse as I found out later.
And so I thought my move was just right.
Moving from the Guard to the Reserve.
And then the Reserve began to be active.
They began to have more units.
They began to have more support.
Before that time it was all a control group type thing.
And so then when they started having units in that's when I decided to join them and move.
Okay now, was this 1956 then that you moved?
And what was my, what's the date on there?
Well, you became the commander, 17th Artillery, 90th Infantry Division in 1956.
Okay, in 54 I came into that same unit.
No, I came over as the executive officer of a AAA battalion.
Okay, so in 56 then you moved.
I'm sorry, I'm sorry.
Moved in 54.
I became a operation officer, S3.
Wait a minute Terry, let me get my, without my notes or anything.
I became the executive officer of an artillery battalion here in Beaumont.
That isn't on here.
It's not on there.
No.
No.
At 4 1st Group, and I was there a year, and then the 90th Division took it over.
I thought it was just a year, and I didn't... We were at Fort Sale.
General Kidwell came down and told our battalion that the 90th Division was going to take us in as their...
Artillery Battalion and it was going to be re-designated to the AAA, AAA Battalion.
And so then the battalion commander then, John Stranahan, decided he wanted to get out.
So he got out and General Kidwell asked me if I would command it.
I was a major at the time.
Okay, so then you became the commander of the 17th Artillery.
I became the commander of the 17th Artillery.
And tell me, as far as that command was concerned, how many men did you have?
How much artillery did you have?
How much equipment?
And the 7th is what is really known as the 5th of the 17th Artillery.
But we call it the 17th Artillery.
It's 17th Artillery Regiment.
It's an old line regiment, an old army.
We had a full complement of units, five units.
We have the headquarter company,
A battery, B battery, C battery, D battery.
Full-firing batteries and headquarter company.
Head and head.
It was called head and head.
And we had the largest strength of the battalions in the 90th in this area.
We got up to about 410 or 15 people at one time.
It was.
It was.
It was a great side.
And it was over our maximum strength, what we did.
Well, how could you do that?
Well, we took the strength from, we took the quotas from the other battalions throughout the division.
The division commander, General Rutter, told us that you just recruit as much as you want and we'll just take the spaces from the other units, which we did.
And we, this area, just boomed with reservists.
had units in Fort Arthur, Orange.
Why do you think that is?
Why do you think so many people were attracted in the mid-1950s to the reserves?
We worked at it.
We worked at it.
Promoted it.
Promoted it.
Publicity-wise.
Newspaper.
Schools.
Service clubs.
I'd go to service clubs and make speeches all the time.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
I was in the...
I was president of the Kiwanis Club, and I was governor of Kiwanis, so I was very active in civic work.
And the Lions Club would call me and ask me to come make a speech, and the Rotary would come and I'd go make a speech.
And so we really beat the drum for the Army Reserve, and we got the people.
Just people we knew and we didn't know would come and join us.
I had a waiting list for the officers.
Really?
Waiting list.
Just any time an officer had to move out of the unit or something, move out of the city, no problem replacing him.
Just a waiting list.
And I had a tremendous staff.
Milton Bell, who eventually became my executive officer, was an architect.
He owns his own firm now, A&M graduate.
Jack B. Alexander was the S3, Major Alexander.
Became the controller...
of Guff Oil Corporation in Pittsburgh.
Tommy LeBlanc was another one of my majors, and he now owns Guff Coast Supply on IH-10 out here, a multi-million dollar plant out there.
They forage Christmas trees and stuff for the oil fields.
Oh, I could just go on and on and tell you the people who've done well in civilian life.
And they were all members of the unit.
That's a very interesting point.
Do you think that there is some correlation between officers and the local reserve units in the country, we could just make a general statement here, and successful community leaders?
I would say yes.
You bet.
This is, at least it was in our area, where my brother Jimmy
was a colonel who retired as a colonel of the reserve and was the mayor of Beaumont two terms.
And so he was in the reserve.
Why do you think that is?
Well, I think it's the leadership that's in you and you just excel in this type of thing.
And it gets back to that old A&M
The training, self-discipline.
You know, you wanted to take charge and do things.

And we had the, let's see, I'm trying to think of some other, oh, well, the, well, another thing, the sheriff of our county was a retired, he came out of the army as a colonel, MP, and he, you know, people supported the reserve.
And so,
It wasn't something we were fighting.
Everybody was trying to help us.
Okay, now everybody's trying to help you.

During the 1960s, of course, we had some anti-war protests and anti-military feeling in America after, by about 1970, when it appeared that we weren't really winning in Vietnam, although we had been told that it looked like the
White was at the end of the tunnel.
Did you get any anti-military or anti-reserve feeling during those years?
Not really, Terry.
We didn't get any anti-military response from the people.
The feedback wasn't that way.
Well, did you get any pro?
We got, well, what we did get, we got a lot of support and reserve.
Because a lot of people wanted to join.
Join the reserve, yeah.
They didn't want to, you know, be called up and go to Vietnam.
So we had waiting lists then because it was a different reason than it was back when I had the artillery battalion.
Yeah, artillery battalion.
I think this is one of the things that helped me along the way that I learned at A&M.
Okay.
Was to select and...
have around me people who were quality type people, who were smart and dedicated to help me do a job.
I didn't select people to be on the staff because they were my friends.
And I always guarded that.
I helped my friends, no question about it.
I'm a loyal type person.
If you're my friend of mine, I'm very loyal to you.
And I'll stick with you.
And I'll do anything I can.
But if you're a quality type friend and smart, intelligent, and you've got a lot on the ball, and you're my friend, I'm going to promote you and take care of you because you're helping me.
Sure.
Absolutely.
And that was my, I guess it was my secret of why I went along
the route of coming to general.
I always surrounded myself with some good staff people, like the ones I named you a while ago.
Bale, Alexander, Coffin, who owns all the cleaners in Beaumont now.
He was my University of Texas graduate, I was telling you about.
But he was my S4, my supply man.
He got the job done, and he did it for me.
He would tell me a lot of times, Colonel,
We're not doing this right, and we're going to get in trouble.
So I said, well, okay, Dick, what shall we do?
He said, well, I think we ought to do this, this, this, this.
All right.
